newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan's trade surplus keeps surging.
newsitem.headline: Japan's trade surplus keeps surging.

text.p: Japan's contentious trade surplus is continuing to grow, boosted by the yen's weakening earlier this year and a drop in domestic demand following a tax rise in April, which has encouraged Japanese firms to export more.

The Finance Ministry announced on Monday that the trade surplus in the first 20 days of June more than doubled from the same period a year earlier, making it likely that the figure for the whole of June will post a year-on-year rise for the third straight month.

The customs-cleared trade surplus for the 20-day period was 453.20 billion yen ($4.01 billion), up 129.3 percent from the same period a year earlier. Exports rose 19.1 percent, while imports increased 8.5 percent.
"The yen's weakening a while ago is still having an effect (on exports)," a ministry official said after the announcement.
Although he said the effect of currency movements was becoming smaller in nominal terms, he said the yen's weakness early this year was still affecting Japan's exports.
Some currency dealers were prompted by his comments to buy yen, surmising that Japanese authorities view the yen as being still too weak to curb the trade surplus.
Finance Ministry mandarins are seen eager to keep the surplus from growing any further amid renewed pressure from Japan's trade partners.
Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto heard concerns about the surplus from both the United States and Europe at last month's summit of the Group of Seven (G7) industrial nations in Denver.
President Bill Clinton said after the summit that Japan would risk an economic war with the United States if its trade surplus started exploding again.
But some economists said the surplus is likely to have peaked and the contentious indicator may show a much smaller increase later this year.

"We've seen the worst surge in trade surpluses behind us. We are probably going to see a decline in the trade surplus in the second half of this year on the back of a rebound in import growth," said Andrew Shipley, an economist at Schroder Securities (Japan).
Economists say the recent rise in the surplus was brought about by temporary factors including the effects of a rise in the sales tax to five percent from three percent on April 1.
The tax rise depressed imports by dampening domestic private consumption. At the same time, Japanese manufacturers boosted exports to make up for lost sales at home.
The rise in exports "is in response to the the decrease in domestic demand, which in turn is in reaction to the tax rise", the ministry official said.
But some economists said signs of a rise in imports were already evident.
Michael Hartnett, a senior economist at Merrill Lynch Japan, said the import growth seen in Monday's data was encouraging.

He said: "Possibly more of a surprise is the pickup in import growth we saw this morning -- 8.5 percent year-on-year. I think that's the strongest number in year-on-year terms since February 1996, so that might quell some fears that the trade surplus is going to go inexorably upwards." ($1=113 yen)
